subsection.subsectiontext: If a Canadian judgment or a registered Canadian judgment is a TILMA award,

paragraph.paragraphtext: sections 6 (2) (c) (ii) to (iv) and 9 do not apply, and
a reference in section 4 to sections 5 and 6 is deemed to be a reference to sections 5 and 6 (1), (2) (a), (b) and (c) (i), (3) and (4).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a registered Canadian judgment is a TILMA award against the government, the following must accord with the Crown Proceeding Act:

paragraph.paragraphtext: enforcement of that registered Canadian judgment under section 4 of this Act;
an order in respect of that registered Canadian judgment under section 6 (2) (a), (b) or (c) (i) of this Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), nothing in subsection (1) affects the power of the Supreme Court to make, in relation to a registered Canadian judgment that is a TILMA award, any order in relation to the enforcement of that registered Canadian judgment, including, without limitation, any order

paragraph.paragraphtext: staying or limiting the enforcement of that registered Canadian judgment, or
respecting the procedure to be used for the enforcement of that registered Canadian judgment,

section.subsandwich: that the court may make in relation to the enforcement of any other order or judgment of the court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for registration and enforcement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A Canadian judgment that requires a person to pay money must not be registered or enforced under this Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: after the time for enforcement has expired in the province or territory where the judgment was made, or
later than 10 years after the date on which the judgment became enforceable in the province or territory where it was made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Equitable doctrines and rules of law in relation to delay apply to the enforcement of a Canadian judgment, to the extent that it provides for relief other than the payment of money.

change.changenote: Section 6 (2) (c) (i) BEFORE amended by 2010-6-98,Sch 8, effective July 1, 2010).

change.changenote: Section 6 BEFORE amended by 2012-11-6, 9 and 10, effective February 4, 2015 (BC Reg 16/2015).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party to the proceeding in which a registered Canadian judgment was made may apply to the Supreme Court for directions respecting its enforcement.
On an application under subsection (1), the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an order that the judgment be modified as may be required to make it enforceable in conformity with local practice,
make an order stipulating the procedure to be used in enforcing the judgment, or
make an order staying or limiting the enforcement of the judgment, subject to any terms and for any period the court considers appropriate in the circumstances, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: such an order could be made in respect of an order or judgment of the Supreme Court under the applicable Rules of Court or any enactment relating to legal remedies and the enforcement of orders and judgments,

the party against whom enforcement is sought has brought, or intends to bring, in the province or territory where the Canadian judgment was made, a proceeding to set aside, vary or obtain other relief in respect of the judgment,
an order staying or limiting enforcement is in effect in the province or territory where the Canadian judgment was made, or
the judgement is contrary to public policy in British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notwithstanding subsection (2), the Supreme Court must not make an order staying or limiting the enforcement of a registered Canadian judgment solely on the grounds that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the judge, court or tribunal that made the judgment lacked jurisdiction over the subject matter of the proceeding that led to the judgment, or over the party against whom enforcement is sought, under

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: principles of private international law, or
the domestic law of the province or territory where the judgment was made,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Supreme Court would have come to a different decision on a finding of fact or law or on an exercise of discretion from the decision of the judge, court or tribunal that made the judgment, or
a defect existed in the process or proceeding leading to the judgment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for directions must be made under subsection (1) before any measures are taken to enforce a registered Canadian judgment if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the enforceability of the judgment is, by its terms, subject to the satisfaction of a condition, or
the judgment was obtained without notice to the persons bound by it.
